security-plus.name: CompTIA Security+
security-plus.focus: General security concepts, threats, vulnerabilities, architecture, security operations, and security program management and oversight
security-plus.prerequisites: None required; CompTIA Network+ and two years of IT administration experience recommended

cysa-plus.name: CompTIA CySA+
cysa-plus.focus: Security analytics, intrusion detection, vulnerability management, and incident response using behavioral analytics and SIEM tools
cysa-plus.prerequisites: None required; Security+ or Network+ and 4 years of hands-on security analyst experience recommended

pentest-plus.name: CompTIA PenTest+
pentest-plus.focus: Penetration testing, vulnerability assessment, planning and scoping engagements, exploiting vulnerabilities, and reporting findings
pentest-plus.prerequisites: None required; Security+ or Network+ and 3-4 years of hands-on penetration testing experience recommended

network-plus.name: CompTIA Network+
network-plus.focus: Network architecture, network security, network operations, network troubleshooting, and network technologies including cloud and virtualization
network-plus.prerequisites: None required; CompTIA A+ and 9-12 months of networking experience recommended

a-plus.name: CompTIA A+
a-plus.focus: Hardware, networking, mobile devices, operating systems, troubleshooting, security fundamentals, and operational procedures
a-plus.prerequisites: None required; 9-12 months of hands-on experience recommended

sscp.name: (ISC)² SSCP
sscp.focus: Access controls, security operations, risk identification, incident response, cryptography, network and communications security, and systems and application security
sscp.prerequisites: One year of cumulative paid work experience in one or more of the seven SSCP domains, or a relevant degree

cissp.name: (ISC)² CISSP
cissp.focus: Security and risk management, asset security, security architecture, communications and network security, identity and access management, security assessment, security operations, and software development security
cissp.prerequisites: Five years of cumulative paid work experience in two or more of the eight CISSP domains; one year waived with a relevant degree or approved credential

cism.name: ISACA CISM
cism.focus: Information security governance, information risk management, information security program development and management, and information security incident management
cism.prerequisites: Five years of information security management experience; substitutions and waivers available for up to two years

aws-saa.name: AWS Solutions Architect – Associate
aws-saa.focus: Designing resilient architectures, high-performing architectures, secure applications and architectures, and cost-optimized architectures on AWS
aws-saa.prerequisites: None required; one or more years of hands-on experience designing solutions on AWS recommended

aws-sap.name: AWS Solutions Architect – Professional
aws-sap.focus: Advanced architectural design, migrations, cost control, continuous improvement, and complex multi-account AWS environments at enterprise scale
aws-sap.prerequisites: None required; two or more years of hands-on experience designing and deploying cloud architecture on AWS recommended; SAA-C03 strongly recommended

aws-security-specialty.name: AWS Certified Security – Specialty
aws-security-specialty.focus: Threat detection and incident response, security logging and monitoring, infrastructure security, identity and access management, and data protection in AWS environments
aws-security-specialty.prerequisites: None required; five years of IT security experience and two years of hands-on AWS security experience recommended; associate-level AWS cert recommended

azure-az-104.name: Microsoft Azure Administrator
azure-az-104.focus: Managing Azure identities and governance, implementing and managing storage, deploying and managing Azure compute resources, configuring and managing virtual networking, and monitoring and maintaining Azure resources
azure-az-104.prerequisites: None required; six months of hands-on Azure administration experience recommended

azure-az-500.name: Microsoft Azure Security Engineer
azure-az-500.focus: Managing identity and access, securing networking, securing compute, storage, and databases, and managing security operations in Azure environments
azure-az-500.prerequisites: None required; strong understanding of Azure administration (AZ-104 level) and familiarity with security concepts recommended

ccna.name: Cisco CCNA
ccna.passing: 825/1000 (approximate; Cisco does not publish exact passing scores)
ccna.focus: Network fundamentals, network access, IP connectivity, IP services, security fundamentals, and automation and programmability for enterprise networks
ccna.prerequisites: None required; one or more years of experience implementing and administering Cisco solutions recommended

ceh.name: EC-Council CEH
ceh.focus: Ethical hacking methodology, reconnaissance, scanning, enumeration, system hacking, malware threats, sniffing, social engineering, denial of service, session hijacking, web server and application hacking, and cloud security
ceh.prerequisites: Two years of information security experience or official EC-Council training

casp-plus.name: CompTIA CASP+
casp-plus.focus: Enterprise security architecture, advanced risk management, enterprise security operations, technical integration of enterprise security, and research, development, and collaboration
casp-plus.prerequisites: None required; minimum of ten years of IT administration experience including at least five years of hands-on technical security experience recommended

comparisons.title: Security+ vs CySA+
comparisons.description: Security+ covers broad foundational security knowledge, while CySA+ focuses specifically on security analytics and threat detection. Security+ is the starting point for most cybersecurity careers, and CySA+ builds on that foundation with deeper defensive and blue-team skills.

who_should_get.cert1: IT professionals entering cybersecurity who need a vendor-neutral baseline certification, career changers, or anyone meeting DoD 8570 IAT Level II requirements
who_should_get.cert2: Security analysts, SOC analysts, and threat intelligence professionals who already hold Security+ and want to validate hands-on defensive security and SIEM skills

comparisons.recommended_order: Get Security+ first. It establishes the foundational security vocabulary and concepts that CySA+ builds upon. Most job postings requiring CySA+ also expect Security+ as a baseline.
comparisons.study_tips: If you already hold Security+, focus your CySA+ study on hands-on SIEM tools, log analysis, and incident response procedures. Practice with tools like Splunk or Elastic SIEM. About 60% of CySA+ content extends Security+ topics, so leverage that overlap.

comparisons.title: Security+ vs PenTest+
comparisons.description: Security+ provides a broad security foundation covering defense, governance, and operations, while PenTest+ focuses on offensive security techniques including penetration testing and vulnerability exploitation. They represent the defensive and offensive sides of cybersecurity respectively.

who_should_get.cert1: Anyone starting in cybersecurity, IT professionals who need a general security certification, or those pursuing compliance-driven roles requiring broad security knowledge
who_should_get.cert2: Aspiring penetration testers, red team members, or vulnerability assessment professionals who want to validate offensive security skills without the cost of CEH training

comparisons.recommended_order: Get Security+ first. PenTest+ assumes you understand security concepts like network protocols, cryptography, and common vulnerabilities that Security+ covers thoroughly. You need to understand defenses before you can learn to test them.
comparisons.study_tips: For PenTest+, set up a home lab with vulnerable VMs like Hack The Box or TryHackMe. Practice with tools like Nmap, Burp Suite, and Metasploit. PenTest+ has performance-based questions that require practical knowledge, not just memorization.

comparisons.title: Network+ vs Security+
comparisons.description: Network+ focuses on networking infrastructure, troubleshooting, and administration, while Security+ covers cybersecurity fundamentals. Networking knowledge is the backbone of security, making these two certifications highly complementary in a career progression.

who_should_get.cert1: Help desk technicians moving into network administration, IT generalists who need to validate networking skills, or anyone who wants a strong technical foundation before specializing in security
who_should_get.cert2: IT professionals ready to move into cybersecurity, network administrators who want to add security expertise, or anyone who needs to meet DoD 8570 security certification requirements

comparisons.recommended_order: Get Network+ first if you do not already have strong networking fundamentals. About 20-25% of Security+ content involves networking concepts like ports, protocols, and network architecture. If you already have networking experience or a CCNA, skip directly to Security+.
comparisons.study_tips: Study both certifications using the OSI model as your framework. Understanding how data flows through network layers makes Security+ topics like firewalls, IDS/IPS, and network attacks much more intuitive. Professor Messer offers free video courses for both exams.

comparisons.title: A+ vs Network+
comparisons.description: A+ covers foundational IT skills including hardware, software, and troubleshooting, while Network+ specializes in networking technologies and infrastructure. Together they form the traditional CompTIA entry-level career pathway from help desk to network administration.

who_should_get.cert1: Complete beginners to IT with no prior experience, career changers from non-technical fields, or help desk and desktop support candidates who need to demonstrate baseline competency
who_should_get.cert2: Help desk technicians ready to move into network support or administration, IT professionals who already have hardware and OS experience, or those building toward a security or cloud career

comparisons.recommended_order: Get A+ first if you are brand new to IT. A+ covers basic networking concepts that Network+ expands upon. However, if you already have hands-on IT experience or a technical background, you can skip A+ and go directly to Network+.
comparisons.study_tips: For A+, focus on hands-on practice: build a PC, install operating systems, and troubleshoot common issues. For Network+, set up a home lab with a managed switch and practice subnetting until it becomes second nature. Use tools like Packet Tracer to simulate network configurations.

comparisons.title: Security+ vs SSCP
comparisons.description: Both certifications validate foundational security knowledge, but they come from different organizations and carry different weight. Security+ is vendor-neutral and widely recognized in government and DoD roles, while SSCP is an (ISC)² credential that serves as a stepping stone toward CISSP.

who_should_get.cert1: IT professionals targeting government or DoD positions, career changers entering cybersecurity, or anyone who wants the most widely recognized entry-level security certification with no experience prerequisites
who_should_get.cert2: Security practitioners with at least one year of experience who plan to eventually pursue CISSP, or those who prefer (ISC)²'s body of knowledge and want to join the (ISC)² community early

comparisons.recommended_order: Get Security+ first in most cases. It has no experience requirement, broader industry recognition, and satisfies more compliance frameworks. Pursue SSCP afterward if you plan to follow the (ISC)² certification path toward CISSP.
comparisons.study_tips: There is significant overlap between Security+ and SSCP in areas like access controls, cryptography, and network security. If studying for both, focus on the differences: SSCP goes deeper into operational security procedures, while Security+ emphasizes governance and compliance frameworks more heavily.

comparisons.title: CISSP vs CISM
comparisons.description: CISSP and CISM are both premier advanced security certifications but serve different career trajectories. CISSP is broader and more technically oriented, covering eight domains of security practice, while CISM focuses specifically on information security management, governance, and program leadership.

who_should_get.cert1: Senior security professionals, security architects, or security engineers who want to validate broad and deep technical security knowledge across multiple domains
who_should_get.cert2: Information security managers, CISOs, IT risk managers, or governance professionals who focus on managing security programs, policies, and teams rather than hands-on technical implementation

comparisons.recommended_order: Choose based on your career direction rather than a sequential order. If you are technically focused, get CISSP. If you are management focused, get CISM. Many senior security leaders hold both. If you must choose one first, CISSP has broader recognition.
comparisons.study_tips: Both exams test at a managerial and strategic level, not just technical recall. For CISSP, think like a risk advisor who balances security with business needs. For CISM, focus on governance frameworks, risk management processes, and incident management programs. Practice answering questions from a management perspective.

comparisons.title: CISSP vs Security+
comparisons.description: CISSP and Security+ are often compared but serve entirely different career stages. Security+ is an entry-level certification for those starting in cybersecurity, while CISSP is an expert-level credential for seasoned professionals with at least five years of experience.

who_should_get.cert1: Experienced security professionals with five or more years in the field who are targeting senior roles like security manager, security architect, or CISO
who_should_get.cert2: IT professionals entering cybersecurity, junior security analysts, or anyone who needs a recognized baseline security certification without an experience requirement

comparisons.recommended_order: Get Security+ first, gain several years of hands-on security experience, then pursue CISSP. CISSP requires five years of experience to become fully certified, and its content assumes deep familiarity with security concepts that Security+ introduces.
comparisons.study_tips: Do not attempt CISSP until you have real-world security experience. Security+ can be passed with dedicated study alone, but CISSP questions require you to apply judgment built from years of practice. For CISSP, focus on understanding why rather than what, and always choose the answer that best manages risk.

comparisons.title: AWS SAA vs Azure AZ-104
comparisons.description: These certifications validate cloud skills on competing platforms. AWS Solutions Architect Associate focuses on designing cloud architectures, while Azure Administrator focuses on managing and administering Azure environments. The choice often depends on which cloud platform your employer uses.

who_should_get.cert1: Cloud professionals working in AWS environments, startups and tech companies that predominantly use AWS, or architects who design cloud solutions and need to validate their design skills
who_should_get.cert2: IT administrators transitioning to cloud management, organizations using Microsoft 365 and Azure together, or sysadmins in enterprise environments where Microsoft technologies are the standard

comparisons.recommended_order: Choose based on your employer's cloud platform. If your organization has not committed to a platform, AWS has the larger market share and more job postings. However, Azure is growing rapidly in enterprise environments. Getting certified in your daily platform first provides immediate value.
comparisons.study_tips: Both exams reward hands-on experience over memorization. Use the free tiers from AWS and Azure to build real projects. For AWS SAA, focus on understanding service selection and architectural trade-offs. For AZ-104, practice in the Azure Portal and learn PowerShell and CLI commands for resource management.

comparisons.title: CCNA vs Network+
comparisons.description: Both validate networking knowledge, but CCNA is vendor-specific to Cisco while Network+ is vendor-neutral. CCNA goes deeper into routing, switching, and Cisco IOS configuration, while Network+ provides broader coverage of general networking concepts across all platforms.

who_should_get.cert1: Network engineers or administrators working in Cisco-heavy environments, those targeting higher Cisco certifications like CCNP, or professionals who want a more respected and specialized networking credential
who_should_get.cert2: IT generalists who work with multiple vendors, those starting in IT who want a vendor-neutral foundation, government and DoD employees who need a certification on the approved list, or those on a tighter budget

comparisons.recommended_order: If you are new to networking with no experience, start with Network+ for a gentler introduction. If you know your career will be Cisco-focused, go directly to CCNA. Many professionals get Network+ first and then CCNA, but this is not strictly necessary if you have hands-on Cisco experience.
comparisons.study_tips: For CCNA, you must practice on Cisco IOS using Packet Tracer or GNS3. Subnetting, OSPF, and VLAN configuration must be second nature. For Network+, the focus is more conceptual. Both exams cover the OSI model, IP addressing, and common protocols, so studying for one gives you a head start on the other.

comparisons.title: AWS SAA vs AWS SAP
comparisons.description: AWS Solutions Architect Associate and Professional are two levels of the same certification path. SAA validates the ability to design well-architected solutions, while SAP tests advanced skills in complex enterprise architectures, migrations, and multi-account strategies.

who_should_get.cert1: Cloud engineers with one or more years of AWS experience who want to validate their ability to design resilient, cost-efficient architectures on AWS
who_should_get.cert2: Senior cloud architects with two or more years of AWS design experience who work on enterprise-scale projects, complex migrations, or multi-account governance strategies

comparisons.recommended_order: Get SAA first, then SAP. The Professional exam builds directly on Associate-level knowledge and assumes mastery of all SAA topics. Most candidates spend 6-12 months gaining additional experience between the two exams.
comparisons.study_tips: SAA questions are straightforward with clear correct answers. SAP questions present complex scenarios where multiple answers could work, and you must choose the best one. For SAP, study advanced topics like AWS Organizations, cross-region architectures, and migration strategies. Practice with lengthy scenario-based questions.

comparisons.title: Azure AZ-500 vs Security+
comparisons.description: AZ-500 and Security+ both address security, but from very different angles. Security+ is a vendor-neutral foundational security certification, while AZ-500 focuses specifically on implementing security controls and threat protection within Microsoft Azure cloud environments.

who_should_get.cert1: Azure administrators or engineers who need to specialize in cloud security, security professionals working in Microsoft-centric enterprise environments, or those pursuing the Microsoft Certified: Azure Security Engineer Associate role
who_should_get.cert2: Anyone starting in cybersecurity who needs a broad, vendor-neutral security foundation regardless of the platform they will eventually specialize in

comparisons.recommended_order: Get Security+ first for foundational security knowledge, then pursue AZ-500 when you specialize in Azure security. AZ-500 assumes you understand general security concepts like encryption, identity management, and network security that Security+ covers.
comparisons.study_tips: Security+ can be studied entirely from books and videos. AZ-500 requires hands-on Azure experience, particularly with Microsoft Entra ID (formerly Azure AD), Network Security Groups, Azure Firewall, Microsoft Defender for Cloud, and Key Vault. Use an Azure free account and Microsoft Learn modules extensively.

comparisons.title: CEH vs PenTest+
comparisons.description: CEH and PenTest+ both validate offensive security and penetration testing skills, but they differ significantly in cost, approach, and industry perception. CEH is more expensive but has stronger brand recognition, while PenTest+ is more affordable and focuses on hands-on practical skills.

who_should_get.cert1: Penetration testers or ethical hackers who need the CEH brand name for compliance requirements, government contractors where CEH is specifically mandated, or professionals whose employers will cover the higher training costs
who_should_get.cert2: Aspiring penetration testers who want a cost-effective alternative, those who prefer performance-based testing over pure multiple choice, or CompTIA-certified professionals building on their existing Security+ foundation

comparisons.recommended_order: Either can be pursued first as they cover similar territory. PenTest+ is typically more accessible due to lower cost and no mandatory training requirement. If budget is a concern, start with PenTest+. If your target employer specifically requires CEH, prioritize that one.
comparisons.study_tips: Both exams benefit enormously from hands-on practice. Use platforms like TryHackMe, Hack The Box, or VulnHub to practice real-world scenarios. CEH has a broader but shallower coverage of tools, while PenTest+ tests deeper practical application. For either exam, be comfortable with Nmap, Metasploit, Burp Suite, and common scripting for automation.

comparisons.title: CASP+ vs CISSP
comparisons.description: CASP+ and CISSP are both advanced security certifications but serve different professional profiles. CASP+ is designed for hands-on technical practitioners who want to remain in engineering roles, while CISSP is geared toward security leaders and managers who oversee programs and policies.

who_should_get.cert1: Senior security engineers, architects, or technical leads who want an advanced certification but prefer to stay hands-on rather than move into management, or DoD personnel who need an IAT Level III / IAM Level II certification
who_should_get.cert2: Security professionals moving into management, those targeting CISO or security director roles, or anyone who wants the most globally recognized advanced security certification for career mobility

comparisons.recommended_order: Choose based on career path, not difficulty. If you want to remain technical, get CASP+. If you are moving toward management or want broader recognition, get CISSP. CISSP has stronger global brand recognition and typically commands higher salaries, but CASP+ is highly valued in government and DoD roles.
comparisons.study_tips: CASP+ questions are scenario-based and expect you to implement solutions, while CISSP questions expect you to evaluate and recommend from a managerial perspective. For CASP+, focus on enterprise architecture and integration of security solutions. For CISSP, always think about risk management and what is best for the organization overall.

comparisons.title: AWS SAA vs AWS Security Specialty
comparisons.description: AWS Solutions Architect Associate provides broad architectural knowledge across all AWS services, while AWS Security Specialty dives deep into security-specific services and best practices. SAA is a generalist credential, and Security Specialty is for those focused on securing AWS workloads.

who_should_get.cert1: Cloud engineers and architects who design AWS solutions across compute, storage, networking, and databases and need to validate broad architectural competency
who_should_get.cert2: Cloud security engineers, security architects, or compliance professionals who specialize in securing AWS environments using IAM, KMS, GuardDuty, Security Hub, and related services

comparisons.recommended_order: Get SAA first. The Security Specialty exam assumes thorough understanding of AWS services and architecture that SAA covers. Many Security Specialty questions present complex architectures and ask you to identify or fix security issues within them.
comparisons.study_tips: For Security Specialty after SAA, focus on IAM policies and permission boundaries, KMS key management and encryption strategies, VPC security configurations, CloudTrail and Config for auditing, and incident response procedures in AWS. Hands-on experience with AWS security services is essential; build and secure a multi-tier application in your AWS account.

comparisons.title: CySA+ vs CEH
comparisons.description: CySA+ and CEH represent the defensive and offensive sides of cybersecurity respectively. CySA+ validates blue-team skills like threat detection, analysis, and incident response, while CEH validates red-team skills like ethical hacking and penetration testing methodologies.

who_should_get.cert1: SOC analysts, security analysts, threat intelligence analysts, or incident responders who focus on detecting, analyzing, and responding to security threats using defensive tools and techniques
who_should_get.cert2: Penetration testers, ethical hackers, red team members, or security consultants who focus on finding and exploiting vulnerabilities to improve an organization's security posture

comparisons.recommended_order: Choose based on whether you prefer defense or offense. For a well-rounded security career, defensive skills from CySA+ are in higher demand for more available SOC and analyst roles. If you are drawn to offensive security, CEH has strong name recognition. Many experienced professionals eventually earn both.
comparisons.study_tips: For CySA+, practice with SIEM tools, learn to read and analyze log files, and understand incident response frameworks like NIST 800-61. For CEH, focus on hands-on tool usage and the ethical hacking methodology. Both certifications benefit from practice in lab environments; use Security Onion for CySA+ and Kali Linux for CEH.
